sub_topic: Finding the slope of a tangent line to a curve
message_1: What is the slope of the tangent line to the curve y=x^3-4x+1 at the point (2,-3)?
message_2:
To find the slope of the tangent line to the curve y = x^3 - 4x + 1 at the point (2, -3), we need to find the derivative of the function with respect to x and then evaluate it at x = 2.

The function is y = x^3 - 4x + 1.

First, find the derivative dy/dx:
dy/dx = d(x^3)/dx - d(4x)/dx + d(1)/dx

Using the power rule for derivatives, we get:
dy/dx = 3x^2 - 4

Now, evaluate the derivative at x = 2:
dy/dx(2) = 3(2)^2 - 4
dy/dx(2) = 3(4) - 4
dy/dx(2) = 12 - 4
dy/dx(2) = 8

So, the slope of the tangent line to the curve y = x^3 - 4x + 1 at the point (2, -3) is 8.
